repository.corpname: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into one series.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Born on April 25, 1907, Muriel Simonson graduated from Medford High School, Medford, MA, in 1924. The first woman in her family to go to college, Muriel was one of only two Medford freshmen at Jackson College in the fall of 1924. The Simonsons, a middle-class Medford family, lived on 23 and 26 Dudley Street, Medford, Massachusetts. Her father, Wilmot A. Simonson, was a traveling salesman selling fruit drink-mixes, biscuits, and Mrs. Simonson's Lemon Merengue Pies. Like many of her Jackson classmates, Muriel went on to excel in all areas while studying at Jackson College, Tufts' coordinate college for women established in 1910: academics, theater, voice, and theater production, as a sorority member, as a student leader, and as an athlete.

Unknown to Holmes scholars until 2006, Muriel Simonson and John A. Holmes (A1929) became officially engaged in the spring of 1929. John A. Holmes subsequently gave her a black, three-ring binder containing 24 poems written for and to Muriel. Sometime in 1930, the engagement was dissolved for currently unknown reasons, and Muriel went on to marry Jerry's father, Walter John Rhodes (1903-1996), a year later while John A. Holmes became a renowned local poet and professor of English at Tufts in 1934. Muriel, however, kept his poems tucked away at home and only her son's recent donation of her papers to the Digital Collections and Archvies brought them to light.

Like many women of her generation, Muriel stayed home after marriage -- despite her all her talents and her outstanding achievements while she was at Tufts. Her parents did not approve of her wish to become an actress given the profession's questionable reputation and the economic hardships of the late 1920s. Muriel Simonson Rhodes died November 14, 1987.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Material was donated by Jerry Rhodes, Muriel Simonson's son.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection includes family photographs, newspaper clippings from Tufts, theater programs, and a binder of poems by John Holmes given to Muriel Simonson circa 1930.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. No documentation is available regarding the intellectual property rights in this collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes family photographs, newspaper clippings from Tufts, theater programs, and a John Holmes binder of poems given to Muriel Simonson ca 1930.

did.unittitle: Muriel Simonson with her mother at age 1

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Poetry given to Muriel Simonson by John Holmes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Page 3 of poetry notebook given to Muriel Simonson by John A. Holmes, circa 1930. (First two are blank.) Poem begins 'There are faces,/People talk.'

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Page 4 of poetry notebook given to Muriel Simonson by John A. Holmes, circa 1930. Poems begin 'Green candles and clean curtains' and 'I have lived richly friended'

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Page 5 of poetry notebook given to Muriel Simonson by John A. Holmes, circa 1930. Poems begin 'It was all true, it was all true', 'Tall tree against the sky', and 'Did you sing to me'

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Page 6 of poetry notebook given to Muriel Simonson by John A. Holmes, circa 1930. Poems begin 'Even though tomorrow', 'When you have come at last', and 'Make me forget'

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Page 7 of poetry notebook given to Muriel Simonson by John A. Holmes, circa 1930. Poems begin 'You said, This newest height of love', 'I have lingered over making them', and 'You say the love I give you'. Following page is blank.

did.unittitle: John Holmes Poetry - 'Poems For You, Jan. 4 - Feb. 1, 1930'

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Newspaper clipping featuring photograph of field hockey team in uniform, with attached handwritten note. The printed photo caption indicates that this was the 1924 field hockey team, but a handwritten correction indicates that it is the 1925 field hockey team. The note, attached with cellophane tape, reads "This was in the latest issue of the 'Tufts Criterion' (a sort of newspaper) in connection with an article generally concerned with women's lib at Tufts for women. Egad, we thought we never had it so good, and felt completely 'libbed'!! First [indistinguishable] on left is Meg and the next I. Some outfits? My memory of field hockey is lots of fun -- plus"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Back of newspaper clipping featuring photograph of field hockey team in uniform, with attached handwritten note. Handwritten inscription on this side reads "the [indistinguishable] nonsense!" See MS135.001.001.00003.00001.001 for complete information.

did.unittitle: 'Medford girl has leading feminine role in Othello'

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Clipping from unidentified Medford (Mass.) newspaper.

did.unittitle: 'Miss Simonson to Wed Editor Holmes of Tufts'

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Clipping from unidentified Medford (Mass.) newspaper. Includes photograph of Muriel Simonson. Subhead reads: Daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilmot H. Simonson of Dudley St. Engaged to John Albert Holmes, Jr. of West Somerville -- Both are Students at Jackson-Tufts and Receive Their Degrees This Month -- Both Are LEaders in College Activities on the Hill.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Clipping from Boston Post, Nov. 1, 1930. Photograph of Muriel Simonson, with caption: 'As a prominent feature of the celebration of Home-coming Day at Tufts College today, the college Dramatics Club will present Lonsdale's comedy 'The High Road' in Jackson Gym. Miss Muriel Simonson, '29, of Medford, will take a prominent part.'

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Clipping from unidentified newspaper, Oct. 31, 1930. Photograph of Muriel Simonson, with caption: IN COMEDY ROLE: 'The High Road,' Frederick Lonsdale's comedy will have Miss Muriel Simonson of Medford in its cast when it is presented by the Tufts College Dramatics Club in the 'home-coming' day program tomorrow.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Clipping from unidentified newspaper, Oct. 12, 1931, describing marriage of Muriel Simonson to Walter John Rhodes, Jr.

did.unittitle: '17 Residents Here Take Part In Tufts Exercises' - Medford Mercury clipping featuring Muriel Simonson
